In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Here is an implementation of the `wrap_string` function in Julia:

```julia
function wrap_string(s, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(s, " ")
    result = ""

    for word in words
        if length(result) + length(word) > text_width
            result *= "\n"
        elseif !isempty(result)  # not first word
            result *= " "
        end
        result *= word
    end

    return result
end
```
This function takes a string `s` and an optional argument for text width. It splits the input string into words using whitespace as separators, then iterates over each word. For each word, it checks if adding the word to the current line would exceed the max width (i.e., length of the current result + length of the word). If so, it appends a newline before the word. If not and the result is not empty (not on the first word), it adds a space before the word. In any case, it always appends the word to the end of the result string.

Here's an example usage:
```julia
print(wrap_string("This is a test string", 10))
# Output: 
# This is a
# test string
```
